Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It’s 1481. In the city of Seville, devout Catholics are turning themselves 
in to the authorities. They’re confessing to heresy— failure to
follow the beliefs of the Catholic Church. But why? The Spanish Inquisition
has arrived in Seville. The Inquisition began in 1478, 
when Pope Sixtus IV issued a decree authorizing the Catholic monarchs, 
Ferdinand and Isabella, to root out heresy
in the Spanish kingdoms— a confederacy of semi-independent kingdoms in the area that would become
the modern country of Spain. Though the order came from the church,
the monarchs had requested it. When the Inquisition began, 
the Spanish kingdoms were diverse both ethnically and religiously, with Jews, Muslims, and Christians living
in the same regions. The Inquisition quickly turned
its attention to ridding the region of people who were not
part of the Catholic Church. It would last more than 350 years. On the ground, groups called tribunals ran
the Inquisition in each region. Roles on a tribunal could include an arresting constable, 
a prosecuting attorney, inquisitors to question the accused,
and a scribe. A “Grand Inquisitor,” a member of the 
clergy selected by the king and queen, almost always led a tribunal. The Inquisition marked its arrival in each
new place with an “Edict of Grace.” Typically lasting 40 days, the Edict of Grace promised mercy
to those who confess to heresy. After that, the inquisitors persecuted
suspected heretics on the basis of anonymous accusations. So the confessors in Seville probably
didn’t see themselves as actual heretics— instead, they were hedging their bets
by reporting themselves when the consequences were low, rather than risking 
imprisonment or torture if someone else accused them later on. They were right to worry: once the authorities arrested someone, 
accusations were often vague, so the accused didn’t know the reasons 
for their arrest or the identity of their accuser. Victims were imprisoned 
for months or even years. Once arrested, 
their property was confiscated, often leaving their families
on the street. Under these conditions, victims confessed
to the most mundane forms of heresy— like hanging linen to dry on a Saturday. The Inquisition targeted different subsets
of the population over time. In 1492, at the brutal Grand Inquisitor
Tomás de Torquemada’s urging, the monarchs issued a decree giving 
Spanish Jews four months to either convert to Christianity
or leave the kingdom. Thousands were expelled 
and those who stayed risked persecution. Converts to Christianity,
known as conversos, weren’t even safe, because authorities suspected 
them of practicing Judaism in secret. The hatred directed at conversos
was both religious and economic, as conversos made up a large portion
of the upper middle class. The Inquisition eventually
shifted its focus to the moriscos, converts to Christianity from Islam. In 1609, an edict passed forcing
all moriscos to leave. An estimated 300,000 left. Those who remained became 
the Inquisition’s next targets. The inquisitors announced the punishments
of those found guilty of heresy in public gatherings called autos de fé,
or acts of faith. Hundreds of people gathered to watch 
the procession of sinners, mass, sermon, and finally the announcement
of punishments. Most of the accused received punishments
like imprisonment, exile, or having to wear a sanbenito, 
a garment that marked them as a sinner. The worst punishment 
was “relaxado en persona”— a euphemism for burning at the stake. This punishment was relatively uncommon— reserved for unrepentant
and relapsed heretics. Over 350 years after Queen Isabella
started the Inquisition, her namesake, Queen Isabella II, 
formally ended it on July 15th, 1834. The Spanish kingdoms’ dependence 
on the Catholic Church had isolated them while the rest of Europe
experienced the Enlightenment and embraced the separation 
of church and state. Historians still debate the number 
of people killed during the Inquisition. Some suggest over 30,000 
but most estimate between 1,000 and 2,000. The consequences of the Inquisition,
however, reach far beyond fatalities. In some places, an estimated 1/3
of prisoners were tortured. Hundreds of thousands of members 
of religious minorities were forced to leave their homes, and those who remained faced 
discrimination and economic hardship. Smaller inquisitions in Spanish 
colonial territories in the Americas, especially Mexico,
carried their own tolls. Friends turned in friends, 
neighbors accused neighbors, and even family members reported
each other of heresy. Under the Inquisition, people were condemned to live 
in fear and paranoia for centuries.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In what year did the Spanish Inquisition begin?
Options: A. 1478, B. 1492, C. 1504, D. 1389
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In what year did the Spanish Inquisition begin? Options: A. 1478, B. 1481, C. 1492, D. 1609 Correct Option: A
Question 2: What was the primary goal of the Spanish Inquisition, as authorized by Pope Sixtus IV? Options: A. To promote tolerance among different religious groups, B. To root out heresy in the Spanish kingdoms, C. To establish the Catholic Church as a separate entity from the state, D. To punish those who practiced Judaism and Islam Correct Option: B
Question 3: Imagine you are a converso living in Spain during the Inquisition. What would be the most likely reason for you to be persecuted by the authorities? Options: A. You are a member of the upper middle class, B. You are suspected of practicing Judaism in secret, C. You have refused to convert to Christianity, D. You have spoken out against the Catholic Church Correct Option: B
Question 4: Analyze the role of the Grand Inquisitor in the Spanish Inquisition. What was their primary responsibility? Options: A. To lead the tribunal and oversee the persecution of heretics, B. To serve as a scribe and record the confessions of the accused, C. To act as a prosecuting attorney and present evidence against the accused, D. To provide spiritual guidance to those who had confessed to heresy Correct Option: A
Question 5: What was the purpose of the Edict of Grace, which was typically issued by the Inquisition when it arrived in a new region? Options: A. To announce the punishments of those found guilty of heresy, B. To offer mercy to those who confessed to heresy within a certain time period, C. To warn people of the consequences of practicing Judaism or Islam, D. To promote the Catholic Church as the dominant faith in the region Correct Option: B
Question 6: Evaluate the impact of the Spanish Inquisition on the social and economic fabric of Spain. What was one of the significant consequences of the Inquisition? Options: A. The Inquisition led to a period of economic prosperity and social cohesion, B. The Inquisition resulted in the expulsion of thousands of Jews and Muslims, leading to economic hardship and social unrest, C. The Inquisition had no significant impact on the social and economic fabric of Spain, D. The Inquisition led to the establishment of a tolerant and inclusive society Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the name given to the public gatherings where the punishments of those found guilty of heresy were announced? Options: A. Autos de fé, B. Edict of Grace, C. Tribunal, D. Inquisition Correct Option: A
Question 8: Synthesize the information provided in the transcript to explain why the Spanish Inquisition was able to persist for over 350 years. What factors contributed to its longevity? Options: A. The Inquisition was supported by the Catholic Church and the Spanish monarchs, and it was able to adapt to changing circumstances over time, B. The Inquisition was a minor institution that had little impact on Spanish society, C. The Inquisition was opposed by the majority of the Spanish population, but it was able to maintain power through force and intimidation, D. The Inquisition was a necessary institution that helped to maintain social order and protect the Catholic faith Correct Option: A
Question 9: Compare and contrast the treatment of conversos and moriscos during the Spanish Inquisition. How did the Inquisition's approach to these groups differ? Options: A. The Inquisition treated conversos and moriscos equally, and both groups were subject to the same punishments and restrictions, B. The Inquisition was more lenient towards conversos, who were allowed to practice Judaism in secret, C. The Inquisition targeted conversos initially, but later shifted its focus to moriscos, who were forced to leave Spain in 1609, D. The Inquisition had no interest in persecuting conversos or moriscos, and instead focused on other groups Correct Option: C
Question 10: What was the significance of the date July 15th, 1834, in the context of the Spanish Inquisition? Options: A. It marked the beginning of the Inquisition, B. It marked the end of the Inquisition, which was formally abolished by Queen Isabella II, C. It marked the expulsion of the Jews from Spain, D. It marked the establishment of the Catholic Church as the dominant faith in Spain Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 1: In what year did the Spanish Inquisition begin? Options: A. 1478, B. 1481, C. 1492, D. 1609 Correct Option: A**

This question has the same intent, options, and content as the ground truth MCQ, with the correct option being the same (A. 1478). The only difference is the inclusion of different distractor options (B, C, and D), but the overall question and correct answer remain the same.

The index of the most similar generated MCQ is: **1**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:

in to the authorities. They’re confessing to heresy— failure to
follow the beliefs of the Catholic Church. But why? The Spanish Inquisition
has arrived in Seville. The Inquisition began in 1478,

a prosecuting attorney, inquisitors to question the accused,
and a scribe. A “Grand Inquisitor,” a member of the 
clergy selected by the king and queen, almost always led a tribunal. The Inquisition marked its arrival in each

to those who confess to heresy. After that, the inquisitors persecuted
suspected heretics on the basis of anonymous accusations. So the confessors in Seville probably

by reporting themselves when the consequences were low, rather than risking 
imprisonment or torture if someone else accused them later on. They were right to worry: once the authorities arrested someone,

for their arrest or the identity of their accuser. Victims were imprisoned 
for months or even years. Once arrested, 
their property was confiscated, often leaving their families
on the street. Under these conditions, victims confessed
to the most mundane forms of heresy— like hanging linen to dry on a Saturday. The Inquisition targeted different subsets
of the population over time. In 1492, at the brutal Grand Inquisitor
Tomás de Torquemada’s urging, the monarchs issued a decree giving 
Spanish Jews four months to either convert to Christianity
or leave the kingdom. Thousands were expelled 
and those who stayed risked persecution. Converts to Christianity,
known as conversos, weren’t even safe, because authorities suspected 
them of practicing Judaism in secret. The hatred directed at conversos
was both religious and economic, as conversos made up a large portion
of the upper middle class. The Inquisition eventually
shifted its focus to the moriscos, converts to Christianity from Islam. In 1609, an edict passed forcing
all moriscos to leave. An estimated 300,000 left. Those who remained became 
the Inquisition’s next targets. The inquisitors announced the punishments
of those found guilty of heresy in public gatherings called autos de fé,
or acts of faith. Hundreds of people gathered to watch 
the procession of sinners, mass, sermon, and finally the announcement
of punishments. Most of the accused received punishments
like imprisonment, exile, or having to wear a sanbenito, 
a garment that marked them as a sinner. The worst punishment 
was “relaxado en persona”— a euphemism for burning at the stake. This punishment was relatively uncommon— reserved for unrepentant
and relapsed heretics. Over 350 years after Queen Isabella
started the Inquisition, her namesake, Queen Isabella II, 
formally ended it on July 15th, 1834. The Spanish kingdoms’ dependence 
on the Catholic Church had isolated them while the rest of Europe
experienced the Enlightenment and embraced the separation 
of church and state. Historians still debate the number 
of people killed during the Inquisition. Some suggest over 30,000 
but most estimate between 1,000 and 2,000. The consequences of the Inquisition,
however, reach far beyond fatalities. In some places, an estimated 1/3
of prisoners were tortured. Hundreds of thousands of members 
of religious minorities were forced to leave their homes, and those who remained faced 
discrimination and economic hardship. Smaller inquisitions in Spanish 
colonial territories in the Americas, especially Mexico,
carried their own tolls. Friends turned in friends, 
neighbors accused neighbors, and even family members reported
each other of heresy. Under the Inquisition, people were condemned to live 
in fear and paranoia for centuries.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The Spanish Kingdoms in the late 1400s were ethnically and religiously diverse, with residents practicing all but which religion?
Options: A. Christianity, B. Buddhism, C. Islam, D. Judaism
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In what year did the Spanish Inquisition begin? Options: A. 1478, B. 1481, C. 1492, D. 1609 Correct Option: A
Question 2: What was the primary goal of the Spanish Inquisition, as authorized by Pope Sixtus IV? Options: A. To promote tolerance among different religious groups, B. To root out heresy in the Spanish kingdoms, C. To establish the Catholic Church as a separate entity from the state, D. To punish those who practiced Judaism and Islam Correct Option: B
Question 3: Imagine you are a converso living in Spain during the Inquisition. What would be the most likely reason for you to be persecuted by the authorities? Options: A. You are a member of the upper middle class, B. You are suspected of practicing Judaism in secret, C. You have refused to convert to Christianity, D. You have spoken out against the Catholic Church Correct Option: B
Question 4: Analyze the role of the Grand Inquisitor in the Spanish Inquisition. What was their primary responsibility? Options: A. To lead the tribunal and oversee the persecution of heretics, B. To serve as a scribe and record the confessions of the accused, C. To act as a prosecuting attorney and present evidence against the accused, D. To provide spiritual guidance to those who had confessed to heresy Correct Option: A
Question 5: What was the purpose of the Edict of Grace, which was typically issued by the Inquisition when it arrived in a new region? Options: A. To announce the punishments of those found guilty of heresy, B. To offer mercy to those who confessed to heresy within a certain time period, C. To warn people of the consequences of practicing Judaism or Islam, D. To promote the Catholic Church as the dominant faith in the region Correct Option: B
Question 6: Evaluate the impact of the Spanish Inquisition on the social and economic fabric of Spain. What was one of the significant consequences of the Inquisition? Options: A. The Inquisition led to a period of economic prosperity and social cohesion, B. The Inquisition resulted in the expulsion of thousands of Jews and Muslims, leading to economic hardship and social unrest, C. The Inquisition had no significant impact on the social and economic fabric of Spain, D. The Inquisition led to the establishment of a tolerant and inclusive society Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the name given to the public gatherings where the punishments of those found guilty of heresy were announced? Options: A. Autos de fé, B. Edict of Grace, C. Tribunal, D. Inquisition Correct Option: A
Question 8: Synthesize the information provided in the transcript to explain why the Spanish Inquisition was able to persist for over 350 years. What factors contributed to its longevity? Options: A. The Inquisition was supported by the Catholic Church and the Spanish monarchs, and it was able to adapt to changing circumstances over time, B. The Inquisition was a minor institution that had little impact on Spanish society, C. The Inquisition was opposed by the majority of the Spanish population, but it was able to maintain power through force and intimidation, D. The Inquisition was a necessary institution that helped to maintain social order and protect the Catholic faith Correct Option: A
Question 9: Compare and contrast the treatment of conversos and moriscos during the Spanish Inquisition. How did the Inquisition's approach to these groups differ? Options: A. The Inquisition treated conversos and moriscos equally, and both groups were subject to the same punishments and restrictions, B. The Inquisition was more lenient towards conversos, who were allowed to practice Judaism in secret, C. The Inquisition targeted conversos initially, but later shifted its focus to moriscos, who were forced to leave Spain in 1609, D. The Inquisition had no interest in persecuting conversos or moriscos, and instead focused on other groups Correct Option: C
Question 10: What was the significance of the date July 15th, 1834, in the context of the Spanish Inquisition? Options: A. It marked the beginning of the Inquisition, B. It marked the end of the Inquisition, which was formally abolished by Queen Isabella II, C. It marked the expulsion of the Jews from Spain, D. It marked the establishment of the Catholic Church as the dominant faith in Spain Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It’s 1481. In the city of Seville, devout Catholics are turning themselves 
in to the authorities. They’re confessing to heresy— failure to
follow the beliefs of the Catholic Church. But why? The Spanish Inquisition
has arrived in Seville. The Inquisition began in 1478, 
when Pope Sixtus IV issued a decree authorizing the Catholic monarchs, 
Ferdinand and Isabella, to root out heresy
in the Spanish kingdoms— a confederacy of semi-independent kingdoms in the area that would become
the modern country of Spain. Though the order came from the church,
the monarchs had requested it. When the Inquisition began, 
the Spanish kingdoms were diverse both ethnically and religiously, with Jews, Muslims, and Christians living
in the same regions. The Inquisition quickly turned
its attention to ridding the region of people who were not
part of the Catholic Church. It would last more than 350 years. On the ground, groups called tribunals ran
the Inquisition in each region. Roles on a tribunal could include an arresting constable, 
a prosecuting attorney, inquisitors to question the accused,
and a scribe. A “Grand Inquisitor,” a member of the 
clergy selected by the king and queen, almost always led a tribunal. The Inquisition marked its arrival in each
new place with an “Edict of Grace.” Typically lasting 40 days, the Edict of Grace promised mercy
to those who confess to heresy. After that, the inquisitors persecuted
suspected heretics on the basis of anonymous accusations. So the confessors in Seville probably
didn’t see themselves as actual heretics— instead, they were hedging their bets
by reporting themselves when the consequences were low, rather than risking 
imprisonment or torture if someone else accused them later on. They were right to worry: once the authorities arrested someone, 
accusations were often vague, so the accused didn’t know the reasons 
for their arrest or the identity of their accuser. Victims were imprisoned 
for months or even years. Once arrested, 
their property was confiscated, often leaving their families
on the street. Under these conditions, victims confessed
to the most mundane forms of heresy— like hanging linen to dry on a Saturday. The Inquisition targeted different subsets
of the population over time. In 1492, at the brutal Grand Inquisitor
Tomás de Torquemada’s urging, the monarchs issued a decree giving 
Spanish Jews four months to either convert to Christianity
or leave the kingdom. Thousands were expelled 
and those who stayed risked persecution. Converts to Christianity,
known as conversos, weren’t even safe, because authorities suspected 
them of practicing Judaism in secret. The hatred directed at conversos
was both religious and economic, as conversos made up a large portion
of the upper middle class. The Inquisition eventually
shifted its focus to the moriscos, converts to Christianity from Islam. In 1609, an edict passed forcing
all moriscos to leave. An estimated 300,000 left. Those who remained became 
the Inquisition’s next targets. The inquisitors announced the punishments
of those found guilty of heresy in public gatherings called autos de fé,
or acts of faith. Hundreds of people gathered to watch 
the procession of sinners, mass, sermon, and finally the announcement
of punishments. Most of the accused received punishments
like imprisonment, exile, or having to wear a sanbenito, 
a garment that marked them as a sinner. The worst punishment 
was “relaxado en persona”— a euphemism for burning at the stake. This punishment was relatively uncommon— reserved for unrepentant
and relapsed heretics. Over 350 years after Queen Isabella
started the Inquisition, her namesake, Queen Isabella II, 
formally ended it on July 15th, 1834. The Spanish kingdoms’ dependence 
on the Catholic Church had isolated them while the rest of Europe
experienced the Enlightenment and embraced the separation 
of church and state. Historians still debate the number 
of people killed during the Inquisition. Some suggest over 30,000 
but most estimate between 1,000 and 2,000. The consequences of the Inquisition,
however, reach far beyond fatalities. In some places, an estimated 1/3
of prisoners were tortured. Hundreds of thousands of members 
of religious minorities were forced to leave their homes, and those who remained faced 
discrimination and economic hardship. Smaller inquisitions in Spanish 
colonial territories in the Americas, especially Mexico,
carried their own tolls. Friends turned in friends, 
neighbors accused neighbors, and even family members reported
each other of heresy. Under the Inquisition, people were condemned to live 
in fear and paranoia for centuries.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A tribunal was made up of a group of different people including all these roles except which one?
Options: A. Arresting constable, B. Prosecuting attorney, C. Scribe, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

The Inquisition was a minor institution that had little impact on Spanish society, C. The Inquisition was more lenient towards conversos, who were allowed to practice Judaism in secret, C. The Inquisition targeted conversos initially, but later shifted its focus to moriscos, who were forced to leave Spain in 1609, D. The Inquisition had no interest in persecuting conversos or moriscos, and instead focused on other groups Correct Option: C

It marked the end of the Inquisition, which was formally abolished by Queen Isabella II, C. It marked the expulsion of the Jews from Spain, D. It marked the establishment of the Catholic Church as the dominant faith in Spain Correct Option: B

**Transcript**:
It’s 1481. In the city of Seville, devout Catholics are turning themselves 
in to the authorities. They’re confessing to heresy— failure to
follow the beliefs of the Catholic Church. But why? The Spanish Inquisition
has arrived in Seville. The Inquisition began in 1478, 
when Pope Sixtus IV issued a decree authorizing the Catholic monarchs, 
Ferdinand and Isabella, to root out heresy
in the Spanish kingdoms— a confederacy of semi-independent kingdoms in the area that would become
the modern country of Spain. Though the order came from the church,
the monarchs had requested it. When the Inquisition began, 
the Spanish kingdoms were diverse both ethnically and religiously, with Jews, Muslims, and Christians living
in the same regions. The Inquisition quickly turned
its attention to ridding the region of people who were not
part of the Catholic Church. It would last more than 350 years. On the ground, groups called tribunals ran
the Inquisition in each region. Roles on a tribunal could include an arresting constable, 
a prosecuting attorney, inquisitors to question the accused,
and a scribe. A “Grand Inquisitor,” a member of the 
clergy selected by the king and queen, almost always led a tribunal. The Inquisition marked its arrival in each
new place with an “Edict of Grace.” Typically lasting 40 days, the Edict of Grace promised mercy
to those who confess to heresy. After that, the inquisitors persecuted
suspected heretics on the basis of anonymous accusations. So the confessors in Seville probably
didn’t see themselves as actual heretics— instead, they were hedging their bets
by reporting themselves when the consequences were low, rather than risking 
imprisonment or torture if someone else accused them later on. They were right to worry: once the authorities arrested someone, 
accusations were often vague, so the accused didn’t know the reasons 
for their arrest or the identity of their accuser. Victims were imprisoned 
for months or even years. Once arrested, 
their property was confiscated, often leaving their families
on the street. Under these conditions, victims confessed
to the most mundane forms of heresy— like hanging linen to dry on a Saturday. The Inquisition targeted different subsets
of the population over time. In 1492, at the brutal Grand Inquisitor
Tomás de Torquemada’s urging, the monarchs issued a decree giving 
Spanish Jews four months to either convert to Christianity
or leave the kingdom. Thousands were expelled 
and those who stayed risked persecution. Converts to Christianity,
known as conversos, weren’t even safe, because authorities suspected 
them of practicing Judaism in secret. The hatred directed at conversos
was both religious and economic, as conversos made up a large portion
of the upper middle class. The Inquisition eventually
shifted its focus to the moriscos, converts to Christianity from Islam. In 1609, an edict passed forcing
all moriscos to leave. An estimated 300,000 left. Those who remained became 
the Inquisition’s next targets. The inquisitors announced the punishments

or acts of faith. Hundreds of people gathered to watch

but most estimate between 1,000 and 2,000. The consequences of the Inquisition,
however, reach far beyond fatalities. In some places, an estimated 1/3
of prisoners were tortured. Hundreds of thousands of members 
of religious minorities were forced to leave their homes, and those who remained faced 
discrimination and economic hardship. Smaller inquisitions in Spanish 
colonial territories in the Americas, especially Mexico,
carried their own tolls. Friends turned in friends, 
neighbors accused neighbors, and even family members reported
each other of heresy. Under the Inquisition, people were condemned to live 
in fear and paranoia for centuries.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It’s 1481. In the city of Seville, devout Catholics are turning themselves 
in to the authorities. They’re confessing to heresy— failure to
follow the beliefs of the Catholic Church. But why? The Spanish Inquisition
has arrived in Seville. The Inquisition began in 1478, 
when Pope Sixtus IV issued a decree authorizing the Catholic monarchs, 
Ferdinand and Isabella, to root out heresy
in the Spanish kingdoms— a confederacy of semi-independent kingdoms in the area that would become
the modern country of Spain. Though the order came from the church,
the monarchs had requested it. When the Inquisition began, 
the Spanish kingdoms were diverse both ethnically and religiously, with Jews, Muslims, and Christians living
in the same regions. The Inquisition quickly turned
its attention to ridding the region of people who were not
part of the Catholic Church. It would last more than 350 years. On the ground, groups called tribunals ran
the Inquisition in each region. Roles on a tribunal could include an arresting constable, 
a prosecuting attorney, inquisitors to question the accused,
and a scribe. A “Grand Inquisitor,” a member of the 
clergy selected by the king and queen, almost always led a tribunal. The Inquisition marked its arrival in each
new place with an “Edict of Grace.” Typically lasting 40 days, the Edict of Grace promised mercy
to those who confess to heresy. After that, the inquisitors persecuted
suspected heretics on the basis of anonymous accusations. So the confessors in Seville probably
didn’t see themselves as actual heretics— instead, they were hedging their bets
by reporting themselves when the consequences were low, rather than risking 
imprisonment or torture if someone else accused them later on. They were right to worry: once the authorities arrested someone, 
accusations were often vague, so the accused didn’t know the reasons 
for their arrest or the identity of their accuser. Victims were imprisoned 
for months or even years. Once arrested, 
their property was confiscated, often leaving their families
on the street. Under these conditions, victims confessed
to the most mundane forms of heresy— like hanging linen to dry on a Saturday. The Inquisition targeted different subsets
of the population over time. In 1492, at the brutal Grand Inquisitor
Tomás de Torquemada’s urging, the monarchs issued a decree giving 
Spanish Jews four months to either convert to Christianity
or leave the kingdom. Thousands were expelled 
and those who stayed risked persecution. Converts to Christianity,
known as conversos, weren’t even safe, because authorities suspected 
them of practicing Judaism in secret. The hatred directed at conversos
was both religious and economic, as conversos made up a large portion
of the upper middle class. The Inquisition eventually
shifted its focus to the moriscos, converts to Christianity from Islam. In 1609, an edict passed forcing
all moriscos to leave. An estimated 300,000 left. Those who remained became 
the Inquisition’s next targets. The inquisitors announced the punishments
of those found guilty of heresy in public gatherings called autos de fé,
or acts of faith. Hundreds of people gathered to watch 
the procession of sinners, mass, sermon, and finally the announcement
of punishments. Most of the accused received punishments
like imprisonment, exile, or having to wear a sanbenito, 
a garment that marked them as a sinner. The worst punishment 
was “relaxado en persona”— a euphemism for burning at the stake. This punishment was relatively uncommon— reserved for unrepentant
and relapsed heretics. Over 350 years after Queen Isabella
started the Inquisition, her namesake, Queen Isabella II, 
formally ended it on July 15th, 1834. The Spanish kingdoms’ dependence 
on the Catholic Church had isolated them while the rest of Europe
experienced the Enlightenment and embraced the separation 
of church and state. Historians still debate the number 
of people killed during the Inquisition. Some suggest over 30,000 
but most estimate between 1,000 and 2,000. The consequences of the Inquisition,
however, reach far beyond fatalities. In some places, an estimated 1/3
of prisoners were tortured. Hundreds of thousands of members 
of religious minorities were forced to leave their homes, and those who remained faced 
discrimination and economic hardship. Smaller inquisitions in Spanish 
colonial territories in the Americas, especially Mexico,
carried their own tolls. Friends turned in friends, 
neighbors accused neighbors, and even family members reported
each other of heresy. Under the Inquisition, people were condemned to live 
in fear and paranoia for centuries.

Correct Option: D

You are a member of the upper middle class, B. You are suspected of practicing Judaism in secret, C. You have refused to convert to Christianity, D. You have spoken out against the Catholic Church Correct Option: B
Question 4: Analyze the role of the Grand Inquisitor in the Spanish Inquisition. What was their primary responsibility? Options: A. To lead the tribunal and oversee the persecution of heretics, B. To serve as a scribe and record the confessions of the accused, C. To act as a prosecuting attorney and present evidence against the accused, D. To provide spiritual guidance to those who had confessed to heresy Correct Option: A
Question 5: What was the purpose of the Edict of Grace, which was typically issued by the Inquisition when it arrived in a new region? Options: A. To announce the punishments of those found guilty of heresy, B. To offer mercy to those who confessed to heresy within a certain time period, C. To warn people of the consequences of practicing Judaism or Islam, D. To promote the Catholic Church as the dominant faith in the region Correct Option: B
Question 6: Evaluate the impact of the Spanish Inquisition on the social and economic fabric of Spain. What was one of the significant consequences of the Inquisition? Options: A. The Inquisition led to a period of economic prosperity and social cohesion, B. The Inquisition resulted in the expulsion of thousands of Jews and Muslims, leading to economic hardship and social unrest, C. The Inquisition had no significant impact on the social and economic fabric of Spain, D. The Inquisition led to the establishment of a tolerant and inclusive society Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the name given to the public gatherings where the punishments of those found guilty of heresy were announced? Options: A. Autos de fé, B. Edict of Grace, C. Tribunal, D. Inquisition Correct Option: A
Question 8: Synthesize the information provided in the transcript to explain why the Spanish Inquisition was able to persist for over 350 years. What factors contributed to its longevity? Options: A. The Inquisition was supported by the Catholic Church and the Spanish monarchs, and it was able to adapt to changing circumstances over time, B. The Inquisition was a minor institution that had little impact on Spanish society, C. The Inquisition was opposed by the majority of the Spanish population, but it was able to maintain power through force and intimidation, D. The Inquisition was a necessary institution that helped to maintain social order and protect the Catholic faith Correct Option: A
Question 9: Compare and contrast the treatment of conversos and moriscos during the Spanish Inquisition. How did the Inquisition's approach to these groups differ? Options: A. The Inquisition treated conversos and moriscos equally, and both groups were subject to the same punishments and restrictions, B. The Inquisition was more lenient towards conversos, who were allowed to practice Judaism in secret, C. The Inquisition targeted conversos initially, but later shifted its focus to moriscos, who were forced to leave Spain in 1609, D. The Inquisition had no interest in persecuting conversos or moriscos, and instead focused on other groups Correct Option: C
Question 10: What was the significance of the date July 15th, 1834, in the context of the Spanish Inquisition? Options: A. It marked the beginning of the Inquisition, B. It marked the end of the Inquisition, which was formally abolished by Queen Isabella II, C. It marked the expulsion of the Jews from Spain, D. It marked the establishment of the Catholic Church as the dominant faith in Spain Correct Option: B

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 10.

The correct option for Question 10 also matches the correct option for the ground truth MCQ, which is the date July 15th, 1834, marking the formal end of the Spanish Inquisition by Queen Isabella II.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Today, artificial intelligence helps
doctors diagnose patients, pilots fly commercial aircraft, 
and city planners predict traffic. But no matter what these AIs are doing,
the computer scientists who designed them likely don’t know exactly 
how they’re doing it. This is because artificial intelligence 
is often self-taught, working off a simple set of instructions to create a unique array 
of rules and strategies. So how exactly does a machine learn? There are many different ways 
to build self-teaching programs. But they all rely on the three 
basic types of machine learning: unsupervised learning, supervised 
learning, and reinforcement learning. To see these in action, let’s imagine researchers are trying
to pull information from a set of medical data containing
thousands of patient profiles. First up, unsupervised learning. This approach would be ideal
for analyzing all the profiles to find general similarities
and useful patterns. Maybe certain patients have similar
disease presentations, or perhaps a treatment produces
specific sets of side effects. This broad pattern-seeking approach 
can be used to identify similarities between patient profiles 
and find emerging patterns, all without human guidance. But let's imagine doctors are looking
for something more specific. These physicians want 
to create an algorithm for diagnosing a particular condition. They begin by collecting two sets of data— medical images and test results
from both healthy patients and those diagnosed with the condition. Then, they input this data into a program designed to identify features
shared by the sick patients but not the healthy patients. Based on how frequently 
it sees certain features, the program will assign values to those
features’ diagnostic significance, generating an algorithm 
for diagnosing future patients. However, unlike unsupervised learning, doctors and computer scientists have 
an active role in what happens next. Doctors will make the final diagnosis and check the accuracy 
of the algorithm’s prediction. Then computer scientists can use
the updated datasets to adjust the program’s parameters 
and improve its accuracy. This hands-on approach is called
supervised learning. Now, let’s say these doctors want 
to design another algorithm to recommend treatment plans. Since these plans
will be implemented in stages, and they may change depending on each
individual's response to treatments, the doctors decide to use
reinforcement learning. This program uses an iterative approach
to gather feedback about which medications, dosages 
and treatments are most effective. Then, it compares that data 
against each patient’s profile to create their unique, optimal 
treatment plan. As the treatments progress and the program
receives more feedback, it can constantly update 
the plan for each patient. None of these three techniques are
inherently smarter than any other. While some require more or less 
human intervention, they all have their own strengths
and weaknesses which makes them best suited
for certain tasks. However, by using them together, researchers can build complex AI systems, where individual programs can 
supervise and teach each other. For example, 
when our unsupervised learning program finds groups of patients that are similar, it could send that data to a connected 
supervised learning program. That program could then incorporate 
this information into its predictions. Or perhaps dozens of reinforcement
learning programs might simulate potential patient outcomes to collect feedback 
about different treatment plans. There are numerous ways to create
these machine-learning systems, and perhaps the most promising models are those that mimic the relationship 
between neurons in the brain. These artificial neural networks can use
millions of connections to tackle difficult tasks like 
image recognition, speech recognition, and even language translation. However, the more self-directed
these models become, the harder it is for computer scientists to determine how these self-taught 
algorithms arrive at their solution. Researchers are already looking at ways 
to make machine learning more transparent. But as AI becomes more involved
in our everyday lives, these enigmatic decisions have
increasingly large impacts on our work, health, and safety. So as machines continue learning 
to investigate, negotiate and communicate, we must also consider how to teach them 
to teach each other to operate ethically.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How does supervised machine learning figure out what rules to follow to do a task?
Options: A. The data scientist has to learn the rules and program them for the computer to follow, B. The rules are learned by the computer on its own, C. The rules are found by mathematical proof
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What are the three basic types of machine learning? Options: A. Unsupervised learning, supervised learning, and deep learning, B. Unsupervised learning, supervised learning, and reinforcement learning, C. Supervised learning, reinforcement learning, and artificial neural networks, D. Unsupervised learning, reinforcement learning, and natural language processing Correct Option: B
Question 2: Describe the primary difference between unsupervised learning and supervised learning. Options: A. Unsupervised learning requires human guidance, while supervised learning does not., B. Unsupervised learning seeks general patterns, while supervised learning seeks specific features., C. Unsupervised learning generates algorithms, while supervised learning adjusts parameters., D. Unsupervised learning is used for image recognition, while supervised learning is used for speech recognition. Correct Option: B
Question 3: A doctor wants to design an algorithm to diagnose a particular condition. Which type of machine learning would be most suitable for this task? Options: A. Unsupervised learning, B. Supervised learning, C. Reinforcement learning, D. Artificial neural networks Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the primary advantage of using reinforcement learning in designing treatment plans? Options: A. It allows for real-time updates based on patient responses., B. It eliminates the need for human intervention., C. It provides a broad pattern-seeking approach., D. It generates a unique array of rules and strategies. Correct Option: A
Question 5: How do artificial neural networks tackle difficult tasks like image recognition and language translation? Options: A. By using millions of connections to mimic the relationship between neurons in the brain., B. By relying on a simple set of instructions to create a unique array of rules and strategies., C. By seeking general patterns and useful relationships., D. By assigning values to features' diagnostic significance. Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is a potential concern as AI becomes more involved in our everyday lives? Options: A. Machines will become too intelligent and surpass human capabilities., B. Machines will make decisions that have increasingly large impacts on our work, health, and safety., C. Machines will require too much human intervention and guidance., D. Machines will not be able to learn and adapt quickly enough. Correct Option: B
Question 7: How can researchers build complex AI systems using the three basic types of machine learning? Options: A. By using each type of learning in isolation to tackle specific tasks., B. By combining the strengths of each type of learning to create a hybrid approach., C. By relying solely on unsupervised learning to generate algorithms., D. By using reinforcement learning to simulate potential patient outcomes. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the primary challenge in understanding how self-taught algorithms arrive at their solutions? Options: A. The complexity of the data used to train the algorithms., B. The lack of transparency in the decision-making process., C. The need for human intervention and guidance., D. The limited scope of the tasks being tackled. Correct Option: B
Question 9: How can researchers address the concern of making machine learning more transparent? Options: A. By developing new types of machine learning that are inherently more transparent., B. By using artificial neural networks to mimic the relationship between neurons in the brain., C. By investigating ways to make machine learning more explainable and interpretable., D. By relying solely on supervised learning to generate algorithms. Correct Option: C
Question 10: Why is it essential to consider how to teach machines to operate ethically as they become more involved in our everyday lives? Options: A. Because machines will eventually surpass human intelligence and capabilities., B. Because machines will make decisions that have significant impacts on our work, health, and safety., C. Because machines will require too much human intervention and guidance., D. Because machines will not be able to learn and adapt quickly enough. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

Although Question 3 does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, it is the closest match in terms of intent and topic. Question 3 asks about the type of machine learning suitable for designing an algorithm to diagnose a particular condition, which is related to the ground truth MCQ's focus on supervised machine learning. 

However, a more accurate match would be a generated MCQ that specifically asks about how supervised machine learning figures out what rules to follow to do a task, which is not present among the provided generated MCQs.

If I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the provided options, I would choose Question 3, but with the understanding that it's not a perfect match.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3

to investigate, negotiate and communicate, we must also consider how to teach them 
to teach each other to operate ethically.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Supervised learning is:
Options: A. When the data scientist watches the AI as it works on a computer in the same room, B. When the data scientist creates a set of rules for the AI to follow and reviews the AI as it works to make sure those rules are followed, C. When the data scientist knows the correct answer for classification tasks and uses them to let the AI learn how to classify new data points on its own
Correct Option: C

from both healthy patients and those diagnosed with the condition. Then, they input this data into a program designed to identify features

Correct Option: C

individual's response to treatments, the doctors decide to use
reinforcement learning. This program uses an iterative approach
to gather feedback about which medications, dosages 
and treatments are most effective. Then, it compares that data 
against each patient’s profile to create their unique, optimal 
treatment plan. As the treatments progress and the program
receives more feedback, it can constantly update 
the plan for each patient. None of these three techniques are
inherently smarter than any other. While some require more or less 
human intervention, they all have their own strengths
and weaknesses which makes them best suited
for certain tasks. However, by using them together, researchers can build complex AI systems, where individual programs can 
supervise and teach each other. For example, 
when our unsupervised learning program finds groups of patients that are similar, it could send that data to a connected 
supervised learning program. That program could then incorporate 
this information into its predictions. Or perhaps dozens of reinforcement
learning programs might simulate potential patient outcomes to collect feedback 
about different treatment plans. There are numerous ways to create
these machine-learning systems, and perhaps the most promising models are those that mimic the relationship 
between neurons in the brain. These artificial neural networks can use
millions of connections to tackle difficult tasks like 
image recognition, speech recognition, and even language translation. However, the more self-directed
these models become, the harder it is for computer scientists to determine how these self-taught 
algorithms arrive at their solution. Researchers are already looking at ways 
to make machine learning more transparent. But as AI becomes more involved
in our everyday lives, these enigmatic decisions have
increasingly large impacts on our work, health, and safety. So as machines continue learning 
to investigate, negotiate and communicate, we must also consider how to teach them 
to teach each other to operate ethically.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Reinforcement learning is:
Options: A. Often used to create a strategy to play games knowing only the goal, B. A set of rules that are set up by researchers to reinforce their goal, C. A technique that requires knowledge of the way humans play games
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What are the three basic types of machine learning? Options: A. Unsupervised learning, supervised learning, and deep learning, B. Unsupervised learning, supervised learning, and reinforcement learning, C. Supervised learning, reinforcement learning, and artificial neural networks, D. Unsupervised learning, reinforcement learning, and natural language processing Correct Option: B
Question 2: Describe the primary difference between unsupervised learning and supervised learning. Options: A. Unsupervised learning requires human guidance, while supervised learning does not., B. Unsupervised learning seeks general patterns, while supervised learning seeks specific features., C. Unsupervised learning generates algorithms, while supervised learning adjusts parameters., D. Unsupervised learning is used for image recognition, while supervised learning is used for speech recognition. Correct Option: B
Question 3: A doctor wants to design an algorithm to diagnose a particular condition. Which type of machine learning would be most suitable for this task? Options: A. Unsupervised learning, B. Supervised learning, C. Reinforcement learning, D. Artificial neural networks Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the primary advantage of using reinforcement learning in designing treatment plans? Options: A. It allows for real-time updates based on patient responses., B. It eliminates the need for human intervention., C. It provides a broad pattern-seeking approach., D. It generates a unique array of rules and strategies. Correct Option: A
Question 5: How do artificial neural networks tackle difficult tasks like image recognition and language translation? Options: A. By using millions of connections to mimic the relationship between neurons in the brain., B. By relying on a simple set of instructions to create a unique array of rules and strategies., C. By seeking general patterns and useful relationships., D. By assigning values to features' diagnostic significance. Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is a potential concern as AI becomes more involved in our everyday lives? Options: A. Machines will become too intelligent and surpass human capabilities., B. Machines will make decisions that have increasingly large impacts on our work, health, and safety., C. Machines will require too much human intervention and guidance., D. Machines will not be able to learn and adapt quickly enough. Correct Option: B
Question 7: How can researchers build complex AI systems using the three basic types of machine learning? Options: A. By using each type of learning in isolation to tackle specific tasks., B. By combining the strengths of each type of learning to create a hybrid approach., C. By relying solely on unsupervised learning to generate algorithms., D. By using reinforcement learning to simulate potential patient outcomes. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the primary challenge in understanding how self-taught algorithms arrive at their solutions? Options: A. The complexity of the data used to train the algorithms., B. The lack of transparency in the decision-making process., C. The need for human intervention and guidance., D. The limited scope of the tasks being tackled. Correct Option: B
Question 9: How can researchers address the concern of making machine learning more transparent? Options: A. By developing new types of machine learning that are inherently more transparent., B. By using artificial neural networks to mimic the relationship between neurons in the brain., C. By investigating ways to make machine learning more explainable and interpretable., D. By relying solely on supervised learning to generate algorithms. Correct Option: C
Question 10: Why is it essential to consider how to teach machines to operate ethically as they become more involved in our everyday lives? Options: A. Because machines will eventually surpass human intelligence and capabilities., B. Because machines will make decisions that have significant impacts on our work, health, and safety., C. Because machines will require too much human intervention and guidance., D. Because machines will not be able to learn and adapt quickly enough. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Today, artificial intelligence helps
doctors diagnose patients, pilots fly commercial aircraft, 
and city planners predict traffic. But no matter what these AIs are doing,
the computer scientists who designed them likely don’t know exactly 
how they’re doing it. This is because artificial intelligence 
is often self-taught, working off a simple set of instructions to create a unique array 
of rules and strategies. So how exactly does a machine learn? There are many different ways 
to build self-teaching programs. But they all rely on the three 
basic types of machine learning: unsupervised learning, supervised 
learning, and reinforcement learning. To see these in action, let’s imagine researchers are trying
to pull information from a set of medical data containing
thousands of patient profiles. First up, unsupervised learning. This approach would be ideal
for analyzing all the profiles to find general similarities
and useful patterns. Maybe certain patients have similar
disease presentations, or perhaps a treatment produces
specific sets of side effects. This broad pattern-seeking approach 
can be used to identify similarities between patient profiles 
and find emerging patterns, all without human guidance. But let's imagine doctors are looking
for something more specific. These physicians want 
to create an algorithm for diagnosing a particular condition. They begin by collecting two sets of data— medical images and test results
from both healthy patients and those diagnosed with the condition. Then, they input this data into a program designed to identify features
shared by the sick patients but not the healthy patients. Based on how frequently 
it sees certain features, the program will assign values to those
features’ diagnostic significance, generating an algorithm 
for diagnosing future patients. However, unlike unsupervised learning, doctors and computer scientists have 
an active role in what happens next. Doctors will make the final diagnosis and check the accuracy 
of the algorithm’s prediction. Then computer scientists can use
the updated datasets to adjust the program’s parameters 
and improve its accuracy. This hands-on approach is called
supervised learning. Now, let’s say these doctors want 
to design another algorithm to recommend treatment plans. Since these plans
will be implemented in stages, and they may change depending on each
individual's response to treatments, the doctors decide to use
reinforcement learning. This program uses an iterative approach
to gather feedback about which medications, dosages 
and treatments are most effective. Then, it compares that data 
against each patient’s profile to create their unique, optimal 
treatment plan. As the treatments progress and the program
receives more feedback, it can constantly update 
the plan for each patient. None of these three techniques are
inherently smarter than any other. While some require more or less 
human intervention, they all have their own strengths
and weaknesses which makes them best suited
for certain tasks. However, by using them together, researchers can build complex AI systems, where individual programs can 
supervise and teach each other. For example, 
when our unsupervised learning program finds groups of patients that are similar, it could send that data to a connected 
supervised learning program. That program could then incorporate 
this information into its predictions. Or perhaps dozens of reinforcement
learning programs might simulate potential patient outcomes to collect feedback 
about different treatment plans. There are numerous ways to create
these machine-learning systems, and perhaps the most promising models are those that mimic the relationship 
between neurons in the brain. These artificial neural networks can use
millions of connections to tackle difficult tasks like 
image recognition, speech recognition, and even language translation. However, the more self-directed
these models become, the harder it is for computer scientists to determine how these self-taught 
algorithms arrive at their solution. Researchers are already looking at ways 
to make machine learning more transparent. But as AI becomes more involved
in our everyday lives, these enigmatic decisions have
increasingly large impacts on our work, health, and safety. So as machines continue learning 
to investigate, negotiate and communicate, we must also consider how to teach them 
to teach each other to operate ethically.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following is NOT true?
Options: A. Artificial Neural Networks mimic the connections between the human brain, B. Artificial neural networks have multiple layers, C. Artificial neural networks can only be used to recognize faces
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What are the three basic types of machine learning? Options: A. Unsupervised learning, supervised learning, and deep learning, B. Unsupervised learning, supervised learning, and reinforcement learning, C. Supervised learning, reinforcement learning, and artificial neural networks, D. Unsupervised learning, reinforcement learning, and natural language processing Correct Option: B
Question 2: Describe the primary difference between unsupervised learning and supervised learning. Options: A. Unsupervised learning requires human guidance, while supervised learning does not., B. Unsupervised learning seeks general patterns, while supervised learning seeks specific features., C. Unsupervised learning generates algorithms, while supervised learning adjusts parameters., D. Unsupervised learning is used for image recognition, while supervised learning is used for speech recognition. Correct Option: B

Question 5: How do artificial neural networks tackle difficult tasks like image recognition and language translation? Options: A. By using millions of connections to mimic the relationship between neurons in the brain., B. By relying on a simple set of instructions to create a unique array of rules and strategies., C. By seeking general patterns and useful relationships., D. By assigning values to features' diagnostic significance. Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is a potential concern as AI becomes more involved in our everyday lives? Options: A. Machines will become too intelligent and surpass human capabilities., B. Machines will make decisions that have increasingly large impacts on our work, health, and safety., C. Machines will require too much human intervention and guidance., D. Machines will not be able to learn and adapt quickly enough. Correct Option: B
Question 7: How can researchers build complex AI systems using the three basic types of machine learning? Options: A. By using each type of learning in isolation to tackle specific tasks., B. By combining the strengths of each type of learning to create a hybrid approach., C. By relying solely on unsupervised learning to generate algorithms., D. By using reinforcement learning to simulate potential patient outcomes. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the primary challenge in understanding how self-taught algorithms arrive at their solutions? Options: A. The complexity of the data used to train the algorithms., B. The lack of transparency in the decision-making process., C. The need for human intervention and guidance., D. The limited scope of the tasks being tackled. Correct Option: B
Question 9: How can researchers address the concern of making machine learning more transparent? Options: A. By developing new types of machine learning that are inherently more transparent., B. By using artificial neural networks to mimic the relationship between neurons in the brain., C. By investigating ways to make machine learning more explainable and interpretable., D. By relying solely on supervised learning to generate algorithms. Correct Option: C

Because machines will eventually surpass human intelligence and capabilities., B. Because machines will make decisions that have significant impacts on our work, health, and safety., C. Because machines will require too much human intervention and guidance., D. Because machines will not be able to learn and adapt quickly enough. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is Question 5.

- The ground truth MCQ asks about the characteristics of Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs), specifically what is NOT true about them.
- Question 5 from the generated MCQs asks how ANNs tackle difficult tasks, and the correct option mentions that ANNs use millions of connections to mimic the relationship between neurons in the brain.

- The options in Question 5 do not directly match the options in the ground truth MCQ, but they do relate to the characteristics and capabilities of ANNs.

However, it's worth noting that none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
After a three-hour concert by her
favorite Norwegian metal band, Anja finds it difficult to hear 
her friend rave about the show. It sounds like he's speaking
from across the room, and it’s tough to make out his muted voice
over the ringing in her ears. By the next morning, 
the effect has mostly worn off, but Anja still has questions. What caused the symptoms? 
Is her hearing going to fully recover? And can she still go to concerts
without damaging her ears? To answer these questions, we first need to understand what sound is
and how we hear it. Like a pebble creating ripples in water, sound is created when displaced molecules
vibrate through space. While sound vibrations can travel
through solids and liquids, our ears have evolved to process
vibrations in the air. These waves of air pressure enter 
our ear canals and bounce off the eardrum. A trio of bones called the ossicular chain then carries those vibrations 
into the cochlea, transforming waves of air pressure
into waves of cochlear fluid. Here, our perception of sound
begins to take form. The waves of fluid move
the basilar membrane, a tissue lined with tens of thousands
of hair cells. The specific vibration of these hair cells
and the stereocilia on top of each one determine the auditory signal 
our brain perceives. Unfortunately, these essential cells
are also quite vulnerable. There are two properties of sound 
that can damage these cells. The first is volume. The louder a sound is, the greater
the pressure of its vibrations. While the ear’s upper limits vary
from person to person, close range exposure to sound
exceeding 120 decibels can instantly bend or blow out hair cells,
resulting in permanent hearing damage. The pressure of more powerful sounds 
can even dislocate the ossicular chain or burst an eardrum. The other side of this equation 
is the sound’s duration. While dangerously loud sounds 
can injure ears almost instantly, hair cells can also be damaged by exposure to lower sound pressure 
for long periods. For example, hearing a hand dryer is safe 
for the 20 seconds you’re using it. But if you listened 
for 8 consecutive hours, this relatively low-pressure sound 
would overwork the stereocilia and swell the hair cell’s 
supporting tissue. Swollen hair cells are unable to vibrate 
with the appropriate speed and accuracy, making hearing muffled. This kind of hearing loss is known
as a temporary threshold shift, and many people will experience 
it at least once in their lifetime. In Anja’s case, 
the loud sounds of the concert only took three hours
to cause this condition. Fortunately, it's a temporary ailment
that usually resolves as swelling decreases over time. In most cases, simply avoiding hazardous sounds 
gives hair cells all they need to recover. One temporary threshold shift isn’t likely
to cause permanent hearing loss. But frequent exposure 
to dangerous sound levels can lead to a wide range 
of hearing disorders, such as the constant buzz of tinnitus or difficulty understanding speech
in loud environments. Overworked hair cells can also generate
dangerous molecules called reactive oxygen species. These molecules
have unpaired electrons, driving them to steal electrons
from nearby cells and cause permanent damage
to the inner ear. There are numerous strategies you can
adopt for preventing hearing loss. Current research around earbud headphone
use suggests keeping your volume at 80% or less if you’ll be listening for 
more than 90 minutes throughout the day. Noise-isolating headphones can also help 
you listen at lower volumes. Getting a baseline understanding 
of your hearing is essential to protecting 
your auditory system. Just like our eyes and teeth,
our ears also need annual check-ups. Not all communities have
access to audiologists, but organizations around the world are
developing portable hearing tests and easy-to-use apps to bring these
vital resources to remote regions. Finally, wear earplugs
when you’re knowingly exposing yourself to loud sounds for extended periods. An earplug’s effectiveness depends 
on how well you’ve inserted it, so be careful to read the instructions. But when worn correctly, they can ensure you'll be able
to hear your favorite band for many nights to come.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When using earbuds for more than 90 minutes throughout the day, keep the volume at ____ or less
Options: A. 50%, B. 75%, C. 80%, D. 37%
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary cause of Anja's difficulty in hearing her friend after the concert? Options: A. The loud sounds of the concert caused permanent damage to her hair cells., B. The duration of the concert caused her hair cells to become swollen., C. The loud sounds of the concert caused a temporary threshold shift in her hearing., D. The concert caused her eardrum to burst. Correct Option: C
Question 2: How do sound vibrations travel through the ear to reach the cochlea? Options: A. Through the ear canal, bouncing off the eardrum, and carried by the ossicular chain., B. Through the ear canal, directly into the cochlea., C. Through the eardrum, into the ear canal, and carried by the ossicular chain., D. Through the ossicular chain, into the ear canal, and bouncing off the eardrum. Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the recommended volume level for earbud headphone use to prevent hearing loss? Options: A. 50% or less for more than 90 minutes., B. 80% or less for more than 90 minutes., C. 100% or less for more than 90 minutes., D. There is no recommended volume level. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the name of the condition Anja experienced after the concert, characterized by muffled hearing? Options: A. Permanent hearing loss., B. Temporary threshold shift., C. Tinnitus., D. Hearing disorder. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What can happen to hair cells when exposed to loud sounds for an extended period? Options: A. They become more sensitive to sound., B. They become swollen and unable to vibrate accurately., C. They become permanently damaged., D. They become more resistant to sound. Correct Option: B
Question 6: How can noise-isolating headphones help prevent hearing loss? Options: A. By increasing the volume of the sound., B. By decreasing the volume of the sound., C. By blocking out background noise., D. By amplifying the sound. Correct Option: B
Question 7: Why is it essential to get a baseline understanding of your hearing? Options: A. To determine the effectiveness of earplugs., B. To diagnose hearing disorders., C. To protect your auditory system., D. To develop portable hearing tests. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What can happen to the inner ear when overworked hair cells generate reactive oxygen species? Options: A. The inner ear becomes more sensitive to sound., B. The inner ear becomes permanently damaged., C. The inner ear becomes more resistant to sound., D. The inner ear becomes swollen. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the purpose of wearing earplugs when exposing yourself to loud sounds for extended periods? Options: A. To increase the volume of the sound., B. To decrease the volume of the sound., C. To block out background noise., D. To protect your hearing. Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the potential long-term effect of frequent exposure to dangerous sound levels? Options: A. Temporary hearing loss., B. Permanent hearing loss., C. Tinnitus., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to determine the recommended volume level for earbud headphone use to prevent hearing loss. The options are also similar, with the correct option being 80% or less for more than 90 minutes.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3.

to hear your favorite band for many nights to come.

Options: A. Temporary Hearing Loss, B. Short-Term Threshold Shift, C. Temporary Threshold Shift, D. Any of the above
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
After a three-hour concert by her
favorite Norwegian metal band, Anja finds it difficult to hear 
her friend rave about the show. It sounds like he's speaking
from across the room, and it’s tough to make out his muted voice
over the ringing in her ears. By the next morning, 
the effect has mostly worn off, but Anja still has questions. What caused the symptoms? 
Is her hearing going to fully recover? And can she still go to concerts
without damaging her ears? To answer these questions, we first need to understand what sound is
and how we hear it. Like a pebble creating ripples in water, sound is created when displaced molecules
vibrate through space. While sound vibrations can travel
through solids and liquids, our ears have evolved to process
vibrations in the air. These waves of air pressure enter 
our ear canals and bounce off the eardrum. A trio of bones called the ossicular chain then carries those vibrations 
into the cochlea, transforming waves of air pressure
into waves of cochlear fluid. Here, our perception of sound
begins to take form. The waves of fluid move
the basilar membrane, a tissue lined with tens of thousands
of hair cells. The specific vibration of these hair cells
and the stereocilia on top of each one determine the auditory signal 
our brain perceives. Unfortunately, these essential cells
are also quite vulnerable. There are two properties of sound 
that can damage these cells. The first is volume. The louder a sound is, the greater
the pressure of its vibrations. While the ear’s upper limits vary
from person to person, close range exposure to sound
exceeding 120 decibels can instantly bend or blow out hair cells,
resulting in permanent hearing damage. The pressure of more powerful sounds 
can even dislocate the ossicular chain or burst an eardrum. The other side of this equation 
is the sound’s duration. While dangerously loud sounds 
can injure ears almost instantly, hair cells can also be damaged by exposure to lower sound pressure 
for long periods. For example, hearing a hand dryer is safe 
for the 20 seconds you’re using it. But if you listened 
for 8 consecutive hours, this relatively low-pressure sound 
would overwork the stereocilia and swell the hair cell’s 
supporting tissue. Swollen hair cells are unable to vibrate 
with the appropriate speed and accuracy, making hearing muffled. This kind of hearing loss is known
as a temporary threshold shift, and many people will experience 
it at least once in their lifetime. In Anja’s case, 
the loud sounds of the concert only took three hours
to cause this condition. Fortunately, it's a temporary ailment
that usually resolves as swelling decreases over time. In most cases, simply avoiding hazardous sounds 
gives hair cells all they need to recover. One temporary threshold shift isn’t likely
to cause permanent hearing loss. But frequent exposure 
to dangerous sound levels can lead to a wide range 
of hearing disorders, such as the constant buzz of tinnitus or difficulty understanding speech
in loud environments. Overworked hair cells can also generate
dangerous molecules called reactive oxygen species. These molecules
have unpaired electrons, driving them to steal electrons
from nearby cells and cause permanent damage
to the inner ear. There are numerous strategies you can
adopt for preventing hearing loss. Current research around earbud headphone
use suggests keeping your volume at 80% or less if you’ll be listening for 
more than 90 minutes throughout the day. Noise-isolating headphones can also help 
you listen at lower volumes. Getting a baseline understanding 
of your hearing is essential to protecting 
your auditory system. Just like our eyes and teeth,
our ears also need annual check-ups. Not all communities have
access to audiologists, but organizations around the world are
developing portable hearing tests and easy-to-use apps to bring these
vital resources to remote regions. Finally, wear earplugs
when you’re knowingly exposing yourself to loud sounds for extended periods. An earplug’s effectiveness depends 
on how well you’ve inserted it, so be careful to read the instructions. But when worn correctly, they can ensure you'll be able
to hear your favorite band for many nights to come.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Injury from sound is dependent on two factors:
Options: A. Volume and duration, B. Pitch and rhythm, C. Pitch and duration, D. Type of sound and volume
Correct Option: A

The duration of the concert caused her hair cells to become swollen., C. The loud sounds of the concert caused a temporary threshold shift in her hearing., D. The concert caused her eardrum to burst. Correct Option: C
Question 2: How do sound vibrations travel through the ear to reach the cochlea? Options: A. Through the ear canal, bouncing off the eardrum, and carried by the ossicular chain., B. Through the ear canal, directly into the cochlea., C. Through the eardrum, into the ear canal, and carried by the ossicular chain., D. Through the ossicular chain, into the ear canal, and bouncing off the eardrum. Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the recommended volume level for earbud headphone use to prevent hearing loss? Options: A. 50% or less for more than 90 minutes., B. 80% or less for more than 90 minutes., C. 100% or less for more than 90 minutes., D. There is no recommended volume level. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the name of the condition Anja experienced after the concert, characterized by muffled hearing? Options: A. Permanent hearing loss., B. Temporary threshold shift., C. Tinnitus., D. Hearing disorder. Correct Option: B
